column6: Stand on mini tramp.
column7: Jump up and land in center of mini tramp allowing knees and hips to bend. Immediately jump back up and repeat.
column8: Handles may be used until balance or technique problems are resolved.
column9: Handles may be used until balance or technique problems are resolved.

column6: Step onto deck of treadmill. Place forearms on padded edge of desk so fingers can be comfortably placed on computer keys. Start treadmill from computer.
column7: Walk on treadmill at comfortable pace allowing for adequate concentration on computer work.
column8: Avoid leaning on desk. Intensity can be altered by incline and speed (mph or kmph).
column9: Avoid leaning on desk. Intensity can be altered by incline and speed (mph or kmph).

column1: Medicine Ball Overhead Throw Sit-up (with partner)
column6: Facing partnerHEPEK sit on floor with knees bent. Hold medicine ball with both hands.
column7: Lie back with ball over head and taps ball to floor. Immediately throw ball to partner from over head while sitting up. Partner catches ball slightly above and in front of head and repeats steps. Continue to volley ball back and forth.
column8: Perform prescribed repetitions or for time. Feet may also be secured under weighted or anchored structure. If feet are not being supported by fixed objectHEPEK legs may need to be extended somewhat to offer adequate counter balance to upper body. If upper back does not come completely down at end of movement, abdominal muscles may only be isometrically involved in exercise. See Spot Reduction Myth. Also see Medicine Ball Sit-up on Machine.
column9: Perform prescribed repetitions or for time. Feet may also be secured under weighted or anchored structure. If feet are not being supported by fixed objectHEPEK legs may need to be extended somewhat to offer adequate counter balance to upper body. If upper back does not come completely down at end of movement, abdominal muscles may only be isometrically involved in exercise. See Spot Reduction Myth. Also see Medicine Ball Sit-up on Machine.

column6: Kneel on floor between two slightly elevated platforms slightly wider that shoulder width apart. Position hands on floor beside sides of platforms. Position upper body off of floor with arms extended. Straighten body and place forefeet back on floor.
column7: Lower body to floor and immediately push body up as fast as possible. As hands leave groundHEPEK rapidly place hands on platforms to sides, catching body before it falls. Lower body again. As soon as slight stretch is felt in chest or shoulders, immediately push upper body upward. Before upper body falls, immediately remove hands off of platforms and catch body by returning hands back on floor between platforms and repeat.
column8: Keep body straight throughout movement. As with any plyometricHEPEK ensure solid strength foundation is first achieved. Joints, particularly shoulders, should be free of biomechanical deficiencies:
column9: Keep body straight throughout movement. As with any plyometricHEPEK ensure solid strength foundation is first achieved. Joints, particularly shoulders, should be free of biomechanical deficiencies:

column6: Stand between high and low pulleysHEPEK facing low pulley. Place one foot back and grasp high pulley stirrup from behind with hand on same side as rear foot. Position stirrup to side of chest and grasp low pulley stirrup with opposite hand (same side as forward foot) with arm extended straight. Face low pulley with hips turned out approximately 45 degrees.
column7: Pull low pulley stirrup back to side of ribcage while pushing high pulley stirrup forward until arm is extendedHEPEK allowing torso to rotate to opposite side.
column8: Return to starting position and repeat.
column9: Return to starting position and repeat.

column6: Lie supine on floor. Position barbell above shoulders with arm straight and vertical.
column7: Stand up while keeping arms straight and vertical above shoulders.
column8: Reverse movement by lying down on floor.
column9: Reverse movement by lying down on floor.

column6: Stand facing balance board. Step on one end of board. Slowly step on other end of board. Balance body weight on top of balance board so board is nearly vertical with little movement. See Balance Board Stand.
column7: Extend arms forward in front of body. Squat down by bending knees slightly forward while allowing hips to bend back behindHEPEK keeping back straight and knees pointed same direction as feet. Descend until thighs are just past parallel to floor. Squat up by extending knees and hips until legs are straight. Return and repeat.
column8: Use upper arm movement to assist with balance. Keep back straightHEPEK chest high, and feet flat on surface; equal distribution of weight through forefoot and heel. Knees should point same direction as feet throughout movement. When finished, shift weight to one side. Step off with highest foot first.
column9: Use upper arm movement to assist with balance. Keep back straightHEPEK chest high, and feet flat on surface; equal distribution of weight through forefoot and heel. Knees should point same direction as feet throughout movement. When finished, shift weight to one side. Step off with highest foot first.

column6: Step onto deck of treadmill and grasp rails. Straddle belt by standing on sides of treadmill. Attach safety tether. Select "quick start" or enter program.
column7: WalkHEPEK keeping pace with treadmill.
column8: Maintain close distance from console. Hand can be placed on rail to for balance. Avoid transferring body weight or 'hanging' onto handle bars. Intensity can be altered by incline and speed (mph or kmph). Spinal rotation occurs during brisk walking.
column9: Maintain close distance from console. Hand can be placed on rail to for balance. Avoid transferring body weight or 'hanging' onto handle bars. Intensity can be altered by incline and speed (mph or kmph). Spinal rotation occurs during brisk walking.

column6: Lie on floor face down and position hands on floorHEPEK shoulder width or slightly wider. Assume plank position by pushing body up with arms extended, body straight, and toes on floor.
column7: Lower body to floor and immediately push body up as fast as possible. As the hands leave groundHEPEK rapidly clap hands together and place back to original position, catching body before it falls. Repeat.
column8: Keep hips and waist straight. As with any plyometricHEPEK ensure solid strength foundation is first achieved. Joints, particularly shoulders should be free of biomechanical deficiencies:
column9: Keep hips and waist straight. As with any plyometricHEPEK ensure solid strength foundation is first achieved. Joints, particularly shoulders should be free of biomechanical deficiencies:

column6: Grasp barbell from rack or clean barbell from floor with overhand gripHEPEK slightly wider than shoulder width. Position bar chest high with torso tight. Retract head back.
column7: Dip body by bending kneesHEPEK hips and ankles slightly. Explosively drive upward with legs, driving barbell up off shoulders, vigorously extending arms overhead. Return to shoulders and repeat.
column8: Also see Slow Motion.
column9: Also see Slow Motion.

column6: Squat down between two heavy kettlebells and grasp one in each hand. Deadlift kettlebells from floor using legs. Stand holding kettlebells with arms straight down to sides.
column7: Walk for distance while counting laps.
column8: Suggested lifting and lower technique from floor will be similar to Trap Bar Deadlift. Traditional strong man event utilizing very heavy weights requires strength and muscular enduranceHEPEK particularly of traps and grip. See exercise performed with traditional loaded bars specialized for Farmer's Walk.
column9: Suggested lifting and lower technique from floor will be similar to Trap Bar Deadlift. Traditional strong man event utilizing very heavy weights requires strength and muscular enduranceHEPEK particularly of traps and grip. See exercise performed with traditional loaded bars specialized for Farmer's Walk.

column6: Place hands on bar and step into pedals. Select coarseHEPEK effort, time, and push start. Place hands on bar for support.
column7: Slightly bend supporting leg and hip while pushing opposite pedel off to side. Glide extended leg back and repeat opposite motion when foot returns near center. Repeat by pushing off from side to side.
column8: Hands may be kept off of handle barsHEPEK either swing arms from side to side or placing hands on hips. If handles are used, avoid transferring too much body weight onto handle bars. Begin at higher resistance for warm up. Intensity can be increased by decreasing resistance thereby increasing speed. Also see Wave Machine.
column9: Hands may be kept off of handle barsHEPEK either swing arms from side to side or placing hands on hips. If handles are used, avoid transferring too much body weight onto handle bars. Begin at higher resistance for warm up. Intensity can be increased by decreasing resistance thereby increasing speed. Also see Wave Machine.

column6: Straddle bench facing high rope pulley. Sit with rope between legs and feet on floor to each side. Grasp rope with both handsHEPEK right arm close to side and left arm extended upward.
column7: With left handHEPEK pull rope down, toward front of body. With right hand, release rope, reach up extending arm and shoulder, and grasp rope. Repeat motion with opposite hands alternating between sides.
column8: None.
column9: None.

column6: Stand over barbell with balls of feet positioned under bar hip's width apart or slightly wider. Squat down and grip bar with overhand grip slightly wider than shoulder width. Position shoulders over bar with back arched tightly. Arms are straight with elbows pointed along bar. Chest is spread and wrists are slightly flexed.
column7: Pull bar up off floor by extending hips and knees. Jump up as high as possible and shrug shoulders.
column8: Bend knees slightly and lower barbell to mid-thigh position. Slowly lower bar with taut lower back and trunk close to vertical.
column9: Bend knees slightly and lower barbell to mid-thigh position. Slowly lower bar with taut lower back and trunk close to vertical.

column6: Step on pedal platforms and grasp sliding grips on rails in each hand.
column7: Kick and glide pedal platforms back and forth while sliding grips along rails back and forth as far as possible.
column8: When familiarizing yourself with this movementHEPEK practice the lower and upper movements separately. Intensity can be altered by resistance and speed (strides per minute). To increase flywheel resistance, turn knob clockwise.
column9: When familiarizing yourself with this movementHEPEK practice the lower and upper movements separately. Intensity can be altered by resistance and speed (strides per minute). To increase flywheel resistance, turn knob clockwise.

column6: Grasp jump rope handles on each side. Initiate side swing mount or start with rope behind body and swing rope from behind over head.
column7: Swing rope in front of bodyHEPEK down to floor. Hop on one leg as rope travels under foot and repeat with same foot. Alternate successive hops between opposite foot. Repeat.
column8: Hop heights should be minimalHEPEK just enough to clear the rope, maximize jump rope efficiency, and decrease joint impact. Intensity can be altered by increasing speed of hops.
column9: Hop heights should be minimalHEPEK just enough to clear the rope, maximize jump rope efficiency, and decrease joint impact. Intensity can be altered by increasing speed of hops.

column6: Stand behind kettlebell with feet slightly wider apart than shoulder width. Bend over at hip with knees bent and back straight. Extend arms downward and grasp kettlebell handle with both hands using overhand grip. Lift kettlebell off of floor and pull forearms against inner thighs while keeping hips and knees bent with low back taut.
column7: Drive hips forwardHEPEK torso upright, and knees straight so kettlebell is pushed forward and upward. Allow kettlebell to swing back down. As kettlebell approaches lower position, fold at hips while bending knees. Forearms make contact with inner thighs permitting kettlebell to swing back under hips. Immediately repeat movement and continue to swing kettlebell. Maintain shoulder to eye level height swings.
column8: Swing kettlebell back down between legs. Allow kettlebell to swing forward but do not extend hips and knees (as would be required to continue the swing). Slow kettlebell's swing and place on floor in original deadlift posture.
column9: Swing kettlebell back down between legs. Allow kettlebell to swing forward but do not extend hips and knees (as would be required to continue the swing). Slow kettlebell's swing and place on floor in original deadlift posture.

column6: Step onto pedal platforms and grasp hand rails. Select "quick start" or enter program.
column7: Place weight on one pedal and allow other pedal to raise. Before lower lever hits bottom or upper lever hits topHEPEK alternate with opposite movement. Repeat.
column8: Avoid transferring body weight onto handle bars. Intensity can be altered by increasing speed (steps per minute). Also see Stepmill.
column9: Avoid transferring body weight onto handle bars. Intensity can be altered by increasing speed (steps per minute). Also see Stepmill.

column6: Raise kettlebell over head. Stand with left arm fully extended upward supporting kettlebell and right arm extended out to side. Stand with legs far apart with feet angled slightly out to the sides.
column7: Bend over to right side with knees straight. Reach toward toes of left foot with right hand. Keep knees straight and kettlebell balanced over left shoulder with both arms extended. Touch left foot. Raise back up to original positionHEPEK maintaining balance of kettlebell over head above left shoulder. Repeat. Continue movement on opposite side.
column8: Exercise emphasizes load balanceHEPEK shoulder mobility, and hamstring flexibility. Also see Dumbbell Windmill or slightly easier version: Kettlebell Bent-knee Windmill.
column9: Exercise emphasizes load balanceHEPEK shoulder mobility, and hamstring flexibility. Also see Dumbbell Windmill or slightly easier version: Kettlebell Bent-knee Windmill.

column6: Raise kettlebell over head. Stand with left arm fully extended upwardHEPEK supporting kettlebell and right arm down to side. Stand with legs far apart with feet angled slightly out to the sides.
column7: Bend over to right side and bend right knee. Reach toward arch of right foot with right hand. Keep left knee straight and kettlebell balanced over left shoulder with both arms extended. Slide right forearm along inner side of right lower leg until finger tips contact floor along side arch of foot. Raise back up to original positionHEPEK maintaining balance of kettlebell over head above left shoulder. Repeat. Continue movement on opposite side.
column8: Exercise emphasizes load balance and shoulder mobility. Since weight is shifted more to bent legHEPEK those hip articulations are emphasized over the straight leg. Also see slightly more challenging Kettlebell Windmill performed with both legs straight.
column9: Exercise emphasizes load balance and shoulder mobility. Since weight is shifted more to bent legHEPEK those hip articulations are emphasized over the straight leg. Also see slightly more challenging Kettlebell Windmill performed with both legs straight.

column6:
As kettlebe


ll approaches shoulder height decelerate handle so kettlebell begins to tilt back. Release kettlebell allowing it to gain height and flip end over end. As soon as kettlebell handle rotates back to topHEPEK grasp kettlebell handle with opposite hand. Return kettlebell between legs. Fold at hips while bending knees so forearm makes contact with inner thigh. Allow kettlebell to swing back under hips.
column8: Dynamic shoulder and shoulder girdle movements are largely passive due to pendulum effect. Following dynamic forces are used during initial pull of kettlebell between legs.
column9: Dynamic shoulder and shoulder girdle movements are largely passive due to pendulum effect. Following dynamic forces are used during initial pull of kettlebell between legs.

column6: Clean and Jerk kettlebell over head. Stand with arm fully extended upward supporting kettlebell.
column7: Step back with leg on opposite side of kettlebell while bending supporting leg. Plant forefoot far back on floor. Lower body by flexing knee and hip of supporting leg until knee of rear leg is almost in contact with floor. Return to original standing position by extending hip and knee of forward supporting leg and return rear leg next to supporting leg. Repeat. Clean and Jerk weight with opposite arm and lunge on other leg.
column8: Keep torso upright during lunge; flexible hip flexors are important. Forward knee should point same direction as foot throughout lunge. A long lunge emphasizes Gluteus Maximus; short lunge emphasizes Quadriceps. Wrist supporting kettlebell should be held straight.
column9: Keep torso upright during lunge; flexible hip flexors are important. Forward knee should point same direction as foot throughout lunge. A long lunge emphasizes Gluteus Maximus; short lunge emphasizes Quadriceps. Wrist supporting kettlebell should be held straight.

column1: Jump Rope: Single Leg Criss Cross
column6: Grasp jump rope handles on each side. Initiate side swing mount or start with rope behind body and swing rope from behind over head. Stand on one foot (base foot) with other foot up off of floor.
column7: As rope travels forward in front of bodyHEPEK cross arms downward in front of hips and jump over rope with base foot. Keep arms crossed while rope swings up behind body. As rope travels forward in front of body, uncross arms back out to sides and jump over rope with base foot and repeat.
column8: Change base foot periodically. Alternating base foot every swingHEPEK would be refered to as 'Jog Step Criss Cross'. Hop heights should be minimal, just enough to clear rope, maximize jump rope efficiency, and decrease joint impact. Intensity can be altered by increasing speed of hops.
column9: Change base foot periodically. Alternating base foot every swingHEPEK would be refered to as 'Jog Step Criss Cross'. Hop heights should be minimal, just enough to clear rope, maximize jump rope efficiency, and decrease joint impact. Intensity can be altered by increasing speed of hops.

column6: Hold two kettlebells in front of shouldersHEPEK one with each arm positioned close to body. Stand with feet shoulder width or slightly wider.
column7: Bend knees slightly forward while allowing hips to bend back behindHEPEK keeping back taut and knees pointed same direction as feet. Descend until thighs are just past parallel to floor. Extend knees and hips until legs are straight. Return and repeat.
column8:
Wrist supporting kettlebell should be held straight. Keep head facing forwardHEPEK back straight, chest high, arms straight to sides, and feet fl


at on floor; equal distribution of weight through forefoot and heel. Knees should point same direction as feet throughout movement. See Squat Analysis and Dumbbell Front Squat.
column9: Wrist supporting kettlebell should be held straight. Keep head facing forwardHEPEK back straight, chest high, arms straight to sides, and feet fl at on floor; equal distribution of weight through forefoot and heel. Knees should point same direction as feet throughout movement. See Squat Analysis and Dumbbell Front Squat.

column6: Release kettlebell as it reaches shoulder height. As kettlebell begins to fall back downHEPEK grasp kettlebell handle with opposite hand. Allow kettlebell to swing back down. As kettlebell approaches lower position, fold at hips while bending knees. Forearm makes contact with inner thigh permitting kettlebell to swing back under hips.
column8: Dynamic shoulder and shoulder girdle movements are largely passive due to pendulum effect. Following dynamic forces are used during initial pull of kettlebell between legs.
column9: Dynamic shoulder and shoulder girdle movements are largely passive due to pendulum effect. Following dynamic forces are used during initial pull of kettlebell between legs.

column6: Stand with barbell with overhand grip slightly wider than shoulder width. Feet point forward hip's width apart or slightly wider. Bend knees and hips so barbell touches mid-thigh; shoulders over bar with back arched. Arms are straight with elbows pointed along bar. Chest is spread and wrists are slightly flexed.
column7: Jump upward extending body. Shrug shoulders and pull barbell upward with armsHEPEK allowing elbows to flex out to sides, keeping bar close to body. Aggressively pull body under bar, rotating elbows around bar. Catch bar on shoulders while moving into squat position. Hitting bottom of squat, stand up immediately.
column8: Bend knees slightly and lower barbell to mid-thigh position.
column9: Bend knees slightly and lower barbell to mid-thigh position.

column6: Stand behind kettlebell with feet slightly wider apart than shoulder width. Bend over at hip with knees bent and back straight. Extend arm downward and grasp kettlebell handle with overhand grip. Lift kettlebell off of floor and pull forearm against inner thighs while keeping hips and knees bent with low back taut.
column7: Drive hips forwardHEPEK torso upright, and knees straight so kettlebell is pushed forward and upward. As kettlebell begins to swing forward vigorously raise shoulder above kettlebell. As kettlebell begins to swing up past the hips, pull kettlebell toward body slightly with elbow pointing outward. As kettlebell continues to rise slightly, decelerate rise of handle allowing kettlebell to rotate in hand into inverted position. Punch kettlebell upward in a overhead straight arm position with kettlebell positioned behind forearm.
column8: Swing kettlebell forward and downward. As kettlebell is swung to lower positionHEPEK fold at hips while bending knees. Allow forearm to make contact with inner thigh, swing kettlebell back under hips, and repeat movement. To stop exercise, place kettlebell on floor. Continue with opposite arm.
column9: Swing kettlebell forward and downward. As kettlebell is swung to lower positionHEPEK fold at hips while bending knees. Allow forearm to make contact with inner thigh, swing kettlebell back under hips, and repeat movement. To stop exercise, place kettlebell on floor. Continue with opposite arm.

column6: Grasp jump rope handles on each side. Initiate side swing mount or start with rope behind body and swing rope from behind over head. Swing rope in front of bodyHEPEK down to floor.
column8: Hop heights should be minimalHEPEK just enough to clear rope, maximize jump rope efficiency, and decrease joint impact. Intensity can be altered by increasing speed of hops.
column9: Hop heights should be minimalHEPEK just enough to clear rope, maximize jump rope efficiency, and decrease joint impact. Intensity can be altered by increasing speed of hops.

column6: Straddle kettlebell with feet slightly wider apart than shoulder width. Squat down with arm extended downward between legs and grasp kettlebell handle with overhand grip. Position shoulder over kettlebell with taut low back and trunk close to vertical.
column7: Pull kettlebell up off floor by extending hips and knees. Once kettlebell is off of groundHEPEK vigorously raise shoulder above kettlebell while keeping it close to body. Jump upward extending body. Raise shoulder and pull kettlebell upward with arm allowing elbow to bend out to side, keeping kettlebell close to body. Drop under kettlebell, rotating arm under kettlebell. Catch kettlebell on outside of arm with wrist straight while moving into partial squat position.
column8: Explosively drive upward with legsHEPEK driving Kettlebell up off arm. Drop body downward and by bending knees as fast as possible while vigorously extending arm upward with wrist straight. Extend both legs.
column9: Explosively drive upward with legsHEPEK driving Kettlebell up off arm. Drop body downward and by bending knees as fast as possible while vigorously extending arm upward with wrist straight. Extend both legs.

column6: Stand between two kettlebells. Squat down with feet flat and grasp handles to sides. Position shoulders over kettlebells with taut low back.
column7: Pull kettlebells up off floor by extending hips and knees. Stand upright with chest high. Lower kettlebells to original position while squatting down with taut lower back.
column8:
Keep feet flat on floorHEPEK hips low, and back taut throughout lift. Knees should point sam


e direction as feet throughout movement. Do not jerk weight from floor. See side view. Also see Trap Bar Deadlift.
column9: Keep feet flat on floorHEPEK hips low, and back taut throughout lift. Knees should point sam e direction as feet throughout movement. Do not jerk weight from floor. See side view. Also see Trap Bar Deadlift.

column1: Lever One Arm Jammer Press (plate loaded)
column6:
Stand inside jammer facing one side with feet slightly wide


r than shoulder width. With far armHEPEK grasp handle with overhand grip. Squat down slightly with handle in front of chest.
column7: Push handles out and up while turning torso forward.
column8: Lower to starting position and repeat.
column9: Lower to starting position and repeat.

column6: Clean and Jerk kettlebell over head. Stand with feet far apart; leg on side of kettlebell should be placed behind and opposite foot should be positioned forward. Arm should be fully extended upward supporting kettlebell.
column7: Squat down by flexing knee and hip of front leg. Allow heel of rear foot to rise up while knee of rear leg bends slightlyHEPEK until it almost makes contact with floor. Return to original standing position by extending hip and knee of forward leg. Repeat. Clean and Jerk weight with opposite arm and squat with other leg forward.
column8: Knees should point same direction as feet throughout movement. Heel of rear foot can be kept elevated off floor throughout movement as shown. Keep torso upright during squat; flexible hip flexors are important. With feet further apart: Gluteus Maximus is emphasizedHEPEK Quadriceps are less emphasized. Wrist supporting kettlebell should be held straight.
column9: Knees should point same direction as feet throughout movement. Heel of rear foot can be kept elevated off floor throughout movement as shown. Keep torso upright during squat; flexible hip flexors are important. With feet further apart: Gluteus Maximus is emphasizedHEPEK Quadriceps are less emphasized. Wrist supporting kettlebell should be held straight.

column6: Stand behind kettlebell with feet slightly wider apart than shoulder width. Bend over at hip with knees bent and back straight. Extend arm downward and grasp kettlebell handle with overhand grip. Lift kettlebell off of floor and pull forearm against inner thighs while keeping hips and knees bent with low back taut.
column7:
Drive hips forwardHEPEK torso upright, and knees straight so kettlebell is pushed forward and upward. Allow kettlebell to swing back down. As kettlebell approaches lower position, fold at hips while bending knees. Forearm makes contact with inner thigh permitting kettlebell to


swing back under hips. Immediately repeat movement and continue to swing kettlebell. Maintain shoulder to eye level height swings.
column8: Swing kettlebell back down between legs. Allow kettlebell to swing forwardHEPEK but do not extend hips and knees (as would be required to continue the swing). Slow kettlebell's swing and place on floor in original deadlift posture.
column9: Swing kettlebell back down between legs. Allow kettlebell to swing forwardHEPEK but do not extend hips and knees (as would be required to continue the swing). Slow kettlebell's swing and place on floor in original deadlift posture.

column6: Stand behind kettlebell with feet slightly wider apart than shoulder width. Bend over at hip with knees bent and back straight. Extend arms downward and grasp kettlebell handle with both hands using overhand grip. Lift kettlebell off of floor and pull forearms against inner thighs while keeping hips and knees bent with low back taut.
column7: Drive hips forwardHEPEK torso upright, and knees straight so kettlebell is pushed forward and upward overhead. Allow kettlebell to swing back down. As kettlebell approaches lower position, fold at hips while bending knees. Forearms make contact with inner thighs permitting kettlebell to swing back under hips. Immediately repeat movement and continue to swing kettlebell.
column8: Swing kettlebell back down between legs. Allow kettlebell to swing forward but do not extend hips and knees (as would be required to continue the swing). Slow kettlebell's swing and place on floor in original deadlift posture.
column9: Swing kettlebell back down between legs. Allow kettlebell to swing forward but do not extend hips and knees (as would be required to continue the swing). Slow kettlebell's swing and place on floor in original deadlift posture.

column6: With a partnerHEPEK stand facing away from each other, slightly less than a meter away. Place feet wider than shoulder width apart, knees slightly bent. First partner holds medicine ball with both hands.
column7: Both individuals rotate to opposite sides. First partner hands medicine ball from behind to second partner who retrieves ball from behind. Both individuals turn to the opposite sides to again exchange medicine ball from behind. Continue to rotate ball in a figure 8 one direction. When finishedHEPEK repeat opposite direction.
column8: Start slowHEPEK gradually increasing speed throughout set. Perform prescribed repetitions or time. Since hips are slightly bent, technically some hip adduction / abduction occurs along with internal / external rotation. See Spot Reduction Myth.
column9: Start slowHEPEK gradually increasing speed throughout set. Perform prescribed repetitions or time. Since hips are slightly bent, technically some hip adduction / abduction occurs along with internal / external rotation. See Spot Reduction Myth.
